title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 10.2.4  Analysis
content:
10.2.4.1  Using the prepared solutions and blanks, analyze chloride, nitrate, phosphate, and sulfate by ion chromatography. Run a reagent blank. Samples and reagent blanks should be prepared and analyzed in triplicate.  
10.2.4.2  Columns — Precolumn should be AG4-A (Dionex) or equivalent, and separation column should be AS4-A (Dionex) or equivalent.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 10.3  Trace Metals Analysis
content: 10.3.1  The following method has giv en satisfactory results in determining metal ion impurities at the values specified for each of the following metals: aluminum (Al), antimony (Sb), arsenic (As), boron (B), calcium $\mathrm { ( C a ) }$ , chromium $( \mathrm { C r } )$ , copper $\mathbf { \Pi } ( \mathbf { C u } )$ , gold (Au), iron (Fe), lead $( \mathrm { P b } )$ , magnesium $( \mathbf { M } \mathbf { g } )$ , manganese (Mn), nickel (Ni), potassium (K), sodium (Na), tin $( \mathsf { S } \mathsf { n } )$ , titanium $\mathrm { ( T i ) }$ , and zinc $( Z \boldsymbol { \mathrm { n } } )$ . Alternate methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate a recovery between $7 5 \mathrm { - } 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified element.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 10.3.2  Special Reagents
content:
10.3.2.1  Nitric Acid, Ultra Pure — Use nitric acid specified for low metal ion content.  
$1 0 . 3 . 2 . 2 4 \%$ Nitric Acid Solution — Di lute $4 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of ultra pure nitric acid to $^ \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ L ~ }$ using water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
10.3.2.3  Water — The water used for a ll the dilution, calibration, and standards should meet, at a minimum, the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127 in regard to cation analysis.  
10.3.2.4  Indium Internal Standard — Make up an indium internal standard solution to a concentration of $2 0 \mathrm { \mu \mathrm { g / m L } }$ (ppm) from an appropriate concentrated indium standard solution.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 10.3.3  Sample Preparation
content: 10.3.3.1  In a clean environment, evapo rate a $5 0 . 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ sample at low heat until approximately $2 0 \textrm { g }$ of the sample remains. Carefully add $1 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of the ultra pure nitric acid and gently warm for several minutes. Cool to room temperature, add $2 5 ~ \mu \mathrm { L }$ of the indium internal standard, and dilute with Type E1.1 water to a final weight of $2 5 . 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ .

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 10.3.4  Analysis
content: 10.3.4.1  Using the prepared solutions and blanks, analyze sodium, potassium, calcium, and iron by graphite furnace atomic absorption (GFAA) and the remaining elements by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP/MS). For calibration, the standards are made up in $4 \%$ nitric acid solution with final concentration of $2 0 ~ \mathrm { n g / g }$ of the indium internal standard. Run a reagent blank.

content: 11.2.1  The following method has giv en satisfactory results in determining anion impurities at the values specified for each of the following anions: chloride (Cl), phosphate $\left( \mathrm { P O } _ { 4 } \right)$ , nitrate $( \mathsf { N O } _ { 3 } )$ , and sulfate $\mathrm { ( S O _ { 4 } ) }$ . Alternate methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate a recovery between $7 5 \mathrm { - } 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified anion.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 11.2.2  Reagents
content:
11.2.2.1  Eluent — Prepare an eluent so lution that is $2 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m M }$ sodium carbonate $\left( \mathrm { N a } _ { 2 } \mathrm { C O } _ { 3 } \right)$ and $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { m M }$ sodium bicarbonate $\mathrm { ( N a H C O _ { 3 } ) }$ ) in deionized water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127. Store eluent under a helium gas blanket.  
11.2.2.2  Regenerant — Prepare a $0 . 0 2 5 \mathrm { ~ N ~ }$ sulfuric acid $\mathrm { ( H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { S O } _ { 4 } )$ in deionized water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
11.2.2.3  Potassium Carbonate Solution — Prepare a solution containing $5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m g }$ of reagent grade potassium carbonate $\left( \mathrm { K } _ { 2 } \mathrm { C O } _ { 3 } \right)$ in $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { m L } }$ of water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 11.2.3  Sample Preparation
content: 11.2.3.1  In a clean environment, place $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of sample into a clean beaker. Add $1 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of a $5 ~ \mathrm { m g / m L }$ potassium carbonate solution and evaporate carefully (at $1 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ to a volume of $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ . Dilute with water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127 to a final volume of $2 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ .

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 11.2.4  Analysis
content:
11.2.4.1  Using the prepared solutions and blanks, analyze chloride, nitrate, phosphate, and sulfate by ion chromatography. Run a reagent blank. Samples and reagent blanks should be prepared and analyzed in triplicate.  
11.2.4.2  Columns — Precolumn should be AG4-A (Dionex) or equivalent, and separation column should be AS4-A (Dionex) or equivalent.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 11.3  Trace Metals Analysis
content: 11.3.1  The following method has giv en satisfactory results in determining metal ion impurities at the values specified for each of the following metals: aluminum (Al), antimony (Sb), arsenic (As), boron (B), calcium $\mathrm { ( C a ) }$ , chromium $( \mathrm { C r } )$ , copper $\mathbf { \Pi } ( \mathbf { C u } )$ , gold (Au), iron (Fe), lead $( { \mathrm { P b } } )$ , magnesium $( \mathbf { M } \mathbf { g } )$ , manganese (Mn), nickel (Ni), potassium (K), sodium (Na), tin $( \mathsf { S } \mathsf { n } )$ , titanium $\mathrm { ( T i ) }$ , and zinc $( Z \boldsymbol { \mathrm { n } } )$ . Alternate methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate a recovery between $7 5 \mathrm { - } 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified element.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 11.3.2  Special Reagents
content:
11.3.2.1  Nitric Acid, Ultrapure — Use nitric acid of low metal ion content.  
11.3.2.2 $2 \%$ Nitric Acid Solution — Di lute ultrapure nitric acid with water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
11.3.2.3  Water — The water used for d ilution, calibration, and standards should meet, at a minimum, the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127 in regard to cation analysis.  
11.3.2.4  Internal Standard Solution — Make up an internal standard solution to a concentration of 1000 $\mu \mathrm { g / m L }$ from appropriate concentrated scandium, yttrium, indium, thulium, and thorium standard solutions.

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 11.3.3  Sample Preparation
content: 11.3.3.1  In a clean environment, in a te flon bottle, evaporate a $5 0 . 0 \ \mathrm { ~ g ~ }$ sample at low heat until approximately $\mathfrak { s } _ { \mathrm { g } }$ of the sample remains. Cool to room temperature, add $1 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { L }$ of the internal standard solution, and dilute with $2 \%$ nitric acid to a final weight of $1 0 . 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ .

title: SEMI C21-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE - # 11.3.4  Analysis
content:
11.3.4.1  Using the prepared solutions and blanks, calibrate the instrument and analyze calcium, iron, sodium, and potassium by cool plasma inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and the remaining elements by normal plasma ICP-MS.  
11.3.4.2  Calculations — All data were r eported relative to an appropriate $1 . 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { g / L }$ standard and corresponding blank solution. Internal standard corrections were applied to the data.

title: SEMI C22-0699GUIDELINE FOR BORON TRIBROMIDE - # 1  Purpose
content: 1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for boron tribromide used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of boron tribromide for which a need has been identified. title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 1  Purpose
content: 1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for buffered oxide etchants used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of buffered oxide etchants for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

content:
2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of buffered oxide etchants used in the semiconductor industry.  
2.2  These standards do not purpor t to address safety issues, if any, associated with their use.  It is the responsibility of the user of these standards to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 5  Terminology
content:
5.1  buffered oxide etchant — any combination of ammonium fluoride and hydrofluoric acid in which the concentrations are expressed in terms of the equivalent relative volumes of $40 \%$ ammonium fluoride solution and $49 \%$ hydrofluoric acid. In the expression, the relative volumes shall be reduced to a ratio of the smallest whole numbers which properly describes the composition. For example, a 7:1 buffered oxide etchant contains the equivalent of 7 volumes of $4 0 . 0 \%$ ammonium fluoride and 1 volume of $49 \%$ hydrofluoric acid.  
NOTE 2: Density at temperature.

title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 6  Composition (Part 1)
content:
Title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 6  Composition

Content: 6.1 For analytical purposes, the ab solute concentrations of ammonium fluoride and hydrofluoric acid corresponding to the above definition shall be calculated according to the following equations. Weight % $\mathrm { { N H } } _ { 4 } \mathrm { { F } } =$ $$ \begin{array} { r l } & { \frac { \mathrm { ( v o l u m e \times \ d e n s i t y \times \ c o n c e n t r a t i o n ) N H } _ { 4 } \mathrm { F } } { \mathrm { ( v o l u m e \times \ d e n s i t y ) } _ { \mathrm { N H } _ { 4 } \mathrm { F } ^ { + } } \mathrm { ( v o l u m e \times \ d e n s i t y ) } _ { \mathrm { H F } } } } \end{array} $$ Weig $$ \begin{array} { r l } & { \mathrm { h t } \mathcal { U } \mathrm { H F } = } \\ & { \frac { \mathrm { ( v o l u m e \times \ d e n s i t y \times \ c o n c e n t r a t i o n ) H F } } { \mathrm { ( v o l u m e \times \ d e n s i t y ) N H _ { 4 } F + \ ( v o l u m e \times \ d e n s i t y ) H F } } } \end{array} $$ where volume and density are expressed in consistent units and concentration is in weight percent to three significant figures.

The absolute percentage concentration of each component follows: $$ \mathcal { I } _ { o } \mathrm { N H _ { 4 } F } = \frac { 7 \times 1 . 1 1 1 \times 4 0 . 0 } { 7 \times 1 . 1 1 1 + 1 \times 1 . 1 5 3 } = 3 4 . 8 \% $$ $$ { \mathrm { W e i g h t } } \ \% \ { \mathrm { ~ H F } } = { \frac { 1 { \times } 1 . 1 5 3 { \times } 4 9 . 0 } { 7 { \times } 1 . 1 1 1 + 1 { \times } 1 . 1 5 3 } } = 6 . 3 3 \% $$

Content: 9.1 Hydrofluoric Acid — Weigh a ccurately approximately 4.0 grams of sample, transfer to a polyethylene beaker, and dilute with water to about 100 mL. Titrate with standardized $^ \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ N ~ }$ sodium hydroxide. The endpoint may be detected colorimetrically by adding 3 drops of methyl red indicator solution and titrating to a definite yellow (no orange) endpoint. As an alternate method, the endpoint may be detected potentiometrically using an HF resistant $\mathrm { \ p H }$ electrode previously standardized in $\mathrm { p H } 4$ and $\mathrm { p H } ~ 7$ buffers. Titrate to $\mathsf { p H } ~ 6 . 5$ with continuous stirring. Save the solution for the determination of ammonium fluoride. $\%$ Hydrofluoric $\mathrm { \ A c i d = \frac { m L \times \Delta N \ o f \ N a O H \times 2 . 0 0 1 } { \Delta W e i g h t \ o f \ s a m p l e ( g ) } }$ 9.2 Ammonium Fluoride — Add $4 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of neutralized formaldehyde solution (see Section 9.2.1) to the solution from the preceding test and stir magnetically for 30 minutes.

The endpoint may be detected colorimetrically by adding 3 drops of methyl red indicator solution and titrating to a definite yellow (no orange) endpoint. title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 10.7  Trace Metals Analysis
content: 10.7.1  The following method has giv en satisfactory results in determining metal ion impurities at the values specified for each of the following metals: aluminum (Al), antimony (Sb), arsenic (As), boron (B), calcium $\mathrm { ( C a ) }$ , chromium $( \mathrm { C r } )$ , copper $\mathbf { \Pi } ( \mathbf { C u } )$ , gold (Au), iron (Fe), lead $( \mathrm { P b } )$ , magnesium $( \mathbf { M g } )$ , manganese (Mn), nickel (Ni), potassium (K), silver $( \operatorname { A g } )$ , sodium (Na), tin $( \mathsf { S } \mathsf { n } )$ , titanium (Ti), and zinc $( Z \boldsymbol { \mathrm { n } } )$ . Alternate methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate a recovery between $7 5 \mathrm { - } 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified element.

title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 10.7.2  Special Reagents
content:
10.7.2.1  Nitric Acid, Ultrapure — Use nitric acid specified for low metal ion content.  
10.7.2.2 $4 \%$ Nitric Acid Solution — Dil ute $4 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of ultrapure nitric acid to $^ \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ L ~ }$ using water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
10.7.2.3  Water — The water used for a ll the dilution, calibration, and standards should meet at a minimum the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127 in regard to cation analysis.  
10.7.2.4  Indium Internal Standard — Make up a indium internal standard solution to a concentration of $2 0 \mathrm { \mu \mathrm { g / m L } }$ (ppm) from an appropriate concentrated indium standard solution.

title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 10.7.3  Sample Preparation
content: 10.7.3.1  In a clean environment, weigh $1 0 . 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ sample into a cleaned Teflon beaker and evaporate the sample on a $2 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ hotplate to near dryness. Carefully add 1 mL of the ultrapure nitric and $3 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of water and gently warm for several minutes. Cool to room temperature, add $2 5 ~ \mu \mathrm { L }$ of the indium internal standard, and dilute with Type E1.1 water to a final weight of $2 5 . 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ .

title: SEMI C23-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR BUFFERED OXIDE ETCHANTS - # 10.7.4  Analysis
content: 10.7.4.1  Using the prepared solutions and blanks, analyze sodium, potassium, calcium, and iron by graphite furnace atomic absorption (GFAA) and the remaining elements by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP/MS). For calibration, the standards are made up in $4 \%$ nitric acid solution with final concentration of $2 0 ~ \mathrm { n g / g }$ of the indium internal standard. Run a reagent blank.

title: SEMI C24-0301SPECIFICATION FOR n-BUTYL ACETATE - # 1  Purpose
content: 1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for n-butyl acetate used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of n-butyl acetate for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

title: SEMI C24-0301SPECIFICATION FOR n-BUTYL ACETATE - # 2  Scope
content:
2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of n-butyl acetate used in the semiconductor industry.  
2.2  These standards do not purpor t to address safety issues, if any, associated with their use.  It is the responsibility of the user of these standards to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

content: 8.8.2.1  In a clean environment, place $2 5 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of sample in a PTFE dish. Add $5 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of Solution A. title: SEMI C25-0699E SPECIFICATION FOR DICHLOROMETHANE (METHYLENE CHLORIDE) - # 8.10.1  Special Reagents
content:
8.10.1.1  Mixed Acid — Mix one volume of ultra pure $70 \%$ nitric acid with four volumes of ultra pure $37 \%$ hydrochloric acid.  
8.10.1.2  Standards — Composite stand ards containing $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { \ p p m }$ of each element in $10 \%$ v/v mixed acid solution are stable for at least 60 days.  
8.10.2  Sample Preparation — Place $2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of mixed acid into a clean $4 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ PTFE beaker. Weigh in $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of sample. Put a PTFE-coated stir bar in the solution and put the beaker in a hood. Evaporate the sample under a current of air, meeting class 100 cleanroom specifications, with stirring to ensure continuous contact of the acid and sample. Do not heat the sample to minimize the loss of volatile organo-metallics. Continue to evaporate until near dryness. Add $2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of mixed acid, mix carefully, and transfer the solution to a $2 5 ~ \mathrm { \ m L }$ volumetric flask. Rinse the beaker and dilute to volume with water.

title: SEMI C25-0699E SPECIFICATION FOR DICHLOROMETHANE (METHYLENE CHLORIDE) - # 8.10.3  Analysis
content:
8.10.3.1  Analyze the sample by plasma emission spectrometry except sodium and potassium by atomic absorption or flame emission within 24 hours of dilution using matrix matched standards. Run a reagent blank and correct the data as necessary.  
NOTE 2:  The trace metal analysis procedure is provisional, pending second source verification of recovery data. To be completed.

title: SEMI C26-0699ESPECIFICATION AND GUIDELINE FOR HEXAMETHYLDISILAZANE(HMDS) - # 1  Purpose
content: 1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for hexamethyldisilazane used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of hexamethyldisilazane for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

title: SEMI C26-0699ESPECIFICATION AND GUIDELINE FOR HEXAMETHYLDISILAZANE(HMDS) - # 2  Scope
content: 2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of hexamethyldisilazane used in the semiconductor industry.

title: SEMI C27-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROCHLORIC ACID - # 1  Purpose
content: 1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for hydrochloric acid used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of hydrochloric acid for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

title: SEMI C27-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROCHLORIC ACID - # 2  Scope
content:
2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of hydrochloric acid used in the semiconductor industry.  
2.2  The VLSI grade purity level is typically required by semiconductor devices with geometries of 0.8–1.2 microns.  
2.3  These specifications and guide lines do not purport to address safety issues, if any, associated with their use.  It is the responsibility of the users of these specifications and guidelines to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

title: SEMI C27-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROCHLORIC ACID - # 8.9.2  Sample Preparation
content: 8.9.2.1  In a clean environment, place $2 5 0 ~ \mathrm { \ m L }$ of sample in a PTFE evaporating dish. Slowly evaporate on a hot plate, avoiding loss of sample by effervescence or spattering until approximately $2 \ \mathrm { \ m L }$ of liquid remains. Note: Evaporation typically requires $2 ~ 1 / 2$ to 4 hours. Cool. Transfer quantitatively to a $5 0 ~ \mathrm { \ m L }$ volumetric flask using $2 \%$ nitric acid for rinsing and dilution to volume. Run a reagent blank.

title: SEMI C27-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROCHLORIC ACID - # 9.2.2  Special Reagents
content:
9.2.2.1  Hydrochloric Acid, Ultrapure Use hydrochloric acid specified for low metal ion content.  
9.2.2.2 $3 . 7 \%$ Hydrochloric Acid Solution — Dilute 20 $\mathbf { g }$ of ultrapure hydrochloric acid to $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ using water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
9.2.2.3  Nitric Acid, Ultrapure — Use nitric acid specified for low metal ion content.  
9.2.2.4 $1 \%$ Nitric Acid Solution — Di lute $1 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of ultrapure nitric acid to $^ \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ L ~ }$ using water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
9.2.2.5  Water — The water used for a ll the dilution, calibration and standards should meet at a minimum the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127 in regard to cation analysis.  
9.2.2.6  Rhodium Internal Standard — Make up the internal standard solution to a concentration of 20 $\mu \mathrm { g / m L }$ (ppm) from the appropriate concentrated standard rhodium solution.

title: SEMI C27-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROCHLORIC ACID - # 9.2.3  Sample Preparation
content:
9.2.3.1  In a clean environment, place $2 . 0 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ of sample into a tared FEP bottle $( 3 0 ~ \mathrm { m L } )$ , dilute with “attainable” water to a final weight of $2 0 . 0 \ \mathrm {  g }$ . Add $2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { L }$ of the rhodium internal standard solution. Run a reagent blank.  
9.2.3.2  Vanadium — In a clean enviro nment, place $2 0 . 0 \textrm { g }$ of sample into a clean PTFE dish. Slowly evaporate on a hot plate to dryness avoiding loss of sample by effervescence or spattering. Dissolve the residue with $5 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of the $1 \%$ nitric acid solution by heating on a hot plate at low temperature for several minutes. Cool to room temperature, dilute to $2 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ with $1 \%$ nitric acid, add $2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { L }$ of the rhodium internal standard, mix well. Run a reagent blank.

title: SEMI C27-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROCHLORIC ACID - # 9.2.4  Analysis
content: 9.2.4.1  Using the prepared solutions a nd blanks, analyze sodium, potassium, calcium and iron by graphite furnace atomic absorption (GFAA) and the remaining elements by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP/MS). For calibration, the standards are made up with the $3 . 7 \%$ hydrochloric acid solution and the rhodium internal standard except for the analysis of vanadium which is performed using $1 \%$ nitric acid as the matrix. All standards must contain 10 $\mathrm { n g / g }$ of rhodium as the internal standard.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 1  Purpose
content: 1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for hydrofluoric acid used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 2  Scope
content:
2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of hydrofluoric acid used in the semiconductor industry.  
NOTICE: This standard does not purport to address safety issues, if any, associated with its use.  It is the responsibility of the users of this standard to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory or other limitations prior to use.

8.6.2.1  In a clean environment, place $2 5 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of sample in a PTFE evaporating dish. Slowly evaporate on a hot plate, avoiding loss of sample by effervescence or spattering until approximately $2 \mathrm { m L }$ of liquid remains.  
NOTE 3:  Evaporation typically requires $2 1 / 2$ to 4 hours.  
Cool. Add $1 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of ultra pure, $70 \%$ nitric acid. While maintaining volume, carefully warm several minutes to dissolve any residue. Cool. Transfer quantitatively to a $5 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ volumetric flask using $2 \%$ nitric acid for rinsing and dilution to volume. Run a reagent blank.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 8.6.3  Analysis
content: 8.6.3.1  Using the acid sample and reagent blank, analyze all specified elements by plasma emission spectroscopy or preferably by ICP-MS.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 9  Grade 2 Procedures
content:
NOTE 4:  Each laboratory is responsible for verifying the validity of the method within its own operation.  
9.1  Non-Metal Impurities — See $\ S 8$ , which contains procedures for the following tests:  
Assay,
Chloride,
Nitrate,
Phosphate, and
Sulfate and Sulfite (as $\mathrm { S O } _ { 4 }$ ).  
9.2  Trace Metals Analysis  
9.2.1  The following method has given satisfactory results in determining trace metal impurities at the value specified for each of the following trace metals: aluminum (Al),  antimony (Sb), arsenic (As), barium (Ba), boron (B), cadmium (Cd), calcium (Ca), chromium $( \mathrm { C r } )$ , copper $\mathrm { ( C u ) }$ , iron (Fe), lead $( \mathrm { P b } )$ , lithium (Li), magnesium $\left( \mathrm { M g } \right)$ , manganese (Mn), nickel (Ni), potassium (K), sodium (Na), tin (Sn), titanium (Ti), vanadium (V), and zinc $( Z \boldsymbol { \mathrm { n } } )$ . Alternate method can be used as long as method validation according to SEMI C1 can be demonstrated.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 9.2.2  Special Reagents
content:
9.2.2.1  Hydrofluoric Acid, Ultra Pure — Use hydrofluoric acid specified for low metal ion content.  
9.2.2.2 $4 . 9 \%$ Hydrofluoric Acid Solution — Dilute $2 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ of ultrapure hydrofluoric acid to $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ using water meetin the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
9.2.2.3  Water — The water used for all the dilution, calibration and standards should meet at a minimum the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127 in regard to cation analysis.  
9.2.2.4  Indium Internal Standard — Make up a internal standard solution to a concentration of $2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { g / m L }$ (ppm) from the appropriate concentrated indium standard solution.  
9.2.3  Sample Preparation — In a clean environment, place $2 . 0 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ of sample into a tared FEP bottle $( 3 0 ~ \mathrm { m L } )$ ), dilute with Type E1.1 water to a final weight of $2 0 . 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ . Add $2 0 { \mu \mathrm { L } }$ of the indium internal standard solution. Run a reagent blank.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 9.2.4  Analysis
content:
9.2.4.1  Using the prepared solutions and blanks, analyze all the specified elements by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP/MS). For calibration, the standards are made up with the $4 . 9 \%$ hydrofluoric acid solution and the indium internal standard such that the final concentration is $2 0 \mathrm { n g / g }$ of indium.  
NOTE 5:  Analysis of dilute hydrofluoric acid requires the use of special hydrofluoric acid resistant sample introduction system for inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. These systems are available from most instrument suppliers.  
NOTE 6:  Analysis of dilute hydrofluoric acid can produce rapid corrosion of nickel cones commonly used in inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, platinum cones should be considered as alternative when performing this analysis.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 10  Grade 3 Procedures (Part 1)
content:
Title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 10  Grade 3 Procedures

Content: 10.1 Assay — See ¶8.1 10.2 Chloride, Nitrate, Sulfate, Phosphate 10.2.1 The above mentioned anions can be determined by ion chromatography using a two dimensional approach. For a detailed procedure, see for example Dionex Technical Note 45. Better results are obtained when using an IonPac ICE-AS1 column instead of the IonPac ICE-AS6 recommended in the TN45. Calibration is preferably done by the method of standard addition. Alternate method can be used as long as method validation according to SEM C1 can be demonstrated. 10.3 Trace Metal Analysis — The following method has given satisfactory results in determining trace metal impurities at the value specified for each of the following trace metals: aluminum (Al), antimony (Sb), arsenic (As), barium (Ba), boron (B), cadmium (Cd), calcium (Ca), chromium (Cr), copper $\mathrm { ( C u ) }$ , iron (Fe), lead $\left( \mathrm { P b } \right)$ , lithium (Li), magnesium $\left( \mathrm { M g } \right)$ , manganese (Mn), nickel (Ni), potassium (K), sodium (Na), tin (Sn), titanium (Ti), vanadium (V),

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 10.3.1  Special Reagents
content:
10.3.1.1  Nitric Acid, Ultra Pure — Use nitric acid specified for ultra low metal ion content.  
10.3.1.2 $3 \%$ Nitric Acid Solution — In a clean environment, place $\boldsymbol { 1 5 } \mathrm { \textrm { g } }$ of Ultra Pure Nitric Acid $\ P 1 0 . 3 . 1 . 1$ into a tared clean $5 0 0 \mathrm { m l }$ FEP bottle.  Dilute to a final weight of $5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ using ultrapure water $\ P 1 0 . 3 . 1 . 3$ .  
10.3.1.3  Water — The water used for all the dilutions, calibrations and standards should meet at a minimum the criteria for Type E1.2 in ASTM D5127 in regard to cation analysis.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 10.3.2  Sample Preparation
content: 10.3.2.1  In a clean environment, place $2 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ of sample into a tared clean $1 2 0 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ FEP bottle.  Dilute to a final weight of $1 0 0 \mathrm { g }$ with the $3 \%$ Nitric Acid Solution $\ P 1 0 . 3 . 1 . 2$ .

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 10.3.3  Analysis
content:
10.3.3.1  Using the prepared solutions, analyze all the specified elements by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). For calibration, blank and standards are made up with the $3 \%$ Nitric Acid Solution $\ P 1 0 . 3 . 1 . 2$ .  
NOTE 7:  Analysis of dilute hydrofluoric acid requires the use of special hydrofluoric acid resistant sample introduction systems for inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. These systems are available from most instrument suppliers.  
NOTE 8:  Analysis of dilute hydrofluoric acid can produce rapid corrosion of nickel cones commonly used in inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, platinum cones should be considered as alternative when performing this analysis.  
NOTE 9:  The analytical methodology described in $\ P 1 0 . 3$ has been validated using a “Reaction / Collision cell” type ICP-MS.
Other instrument type can be used as long as method validation according to SEMI C1 can be demonstrated.

title: SEMI C28-0705 SPECIFICATIONS FOR HYDROFLUORIC ACID - # 11  Grade 4 Procedures
content:
11.1  Assay  — See ¶8.1.  
11.2  Chloride, Nitrate, Sulfate, Phosphate — See ¶10.2.  
11.3  Trace Metal Analysis — See ¶10.3.
